Package com.atakmap.net

Class CertificateManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.atakmap.net.CertificateManager
  • public class CertificateManager
extends java.lang.Object

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class Description
      static class  CertificateManager.CentralTrustManager
      Implementation of a self signed trust manager that will allow for either certificates signed with a certificate installed on the device, one of the pre-supplied DoD certificates or will just validate a self signed certificate.
      static class  CertificateManager.ExtendedSSLSocketFactory

      • ALL_TRUSTING_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER

        public static final javax.net.ssl.HostnameVerifier ALL_TRUSTING_HOSTNAME_VERIFIER
        Provides a permissive host name verified. This is used on tactical networks where host name verification might not be possible.

      • initialize

        public void initialize​(android.content.Context ctx)
        Initialize the current Certificate Manager with the context for the ATAK application. This will install 2 DoD root certificates.
        Parameters:
        ctx - a valid application context

      • getLocalTrustManager

        @Deprecated
public javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager getLocalTrustManager()
        Deprecated.
        Returns a local trust manager. Note that this includes public CAs and the user is cautioned to perform hostname verification. Deprecated in favor of single argument variant
        Returns:
        the trust manager controlled by ATAK and populated with known trusted sources.

      • getLocalTrustManager

        public javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager getLocalTrustManager​(boolean excludePublicCAs)
        Returns a local trust manager. Caller must indicate if it wishes to accept widely available public CAs. Because the public CAs have a wide availability and scope, their inclusion and use should be accompanied by hostname verification to prevent potential man in the middle attacks
        Parameters:
        excludePublicCAs - true to exclude usage of public CAs, false to include them. If included, user should additionally perform hostname verification
        Returns:
        the trust manager controlled by ATAK and populated with known trusted sources.

      • getLocalTrustManager

        public javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager getLocalTrustManager​(java.lang.String host)
        Returns a local trust manager with only trust anchors configured specifically for the given host.
        Parameters:
        host - host for which to provide the trust manager
        Returns:
        the trust manager controlled by ATAK and populated with known trust anchors for the given host.

      • getSystemTrustManager

        public javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager getSystemTrustManager()
        Returns a system trust manager. This is is an unverified trust manager that is supplied with the Android OS and could have not very trustworthy sources in it. This method should only be called if the client then validates things.
        Returns:
        the system trust manager which is not validated.

      • getSockFactory

        public static CertificateManager.ExtendedSSLSocketFactory getSockFactory​(boolean useCache,
                                                                         java.lang.String server,
                                                                         boolean allowAllHostnames)
        Parameters:
        server - base URL to a tak server
        allowAllHostnames - if true, hostname verification will not be applied to the server-presented certificates and, if server is non-null, we only trust certificates we have configured for that server

      • getSockFactory

        public static CertificateManager.ExtendedSSLSocketFactory getSockFactory​(boolean useCache,
                                                                         java.lang.String server)

      • getSockFactory

        public static CertificateManager.ExtendedSSLSocketFactory getSockFactory​(boolean useCache,
                                                                         NetConnectString netConnectString,
                                                                         boolean allowAllHostnames)
        Parameters:
        allowAllHostnames - if true, hostname verification will not be applied to the server-presented certificates and we only trust certificates we have configured for the server identified in netConnectString

      • getSockFactory

        public static CertificateManager.ExtendedSSLSocketFactory getSockFactory​(boolean useCache,
                                                                         NetConnectString netConnectString)

      • invalidate

        public static void invalidate​(java.lang.String host)
        evict all entries in the socketFactories cache for the given host. Entries in the cache are keyed based on a full URL (ie https://host:port/Marti). This function is passed the host and will evict all corresponding cache entries.
        Parameters:
        host - All entries corresponding to this host will be removed

      • setKeyManagerFactory

        public static void setKeyManagerFactory​(KeyManagerFactoryIFace kmf)

                                                                            throws java.security.cert.CertificateException
        Throws:

      • createSSLContext

        public static javax.net.ssl.SSLContext createSSLContext​(javax.net.ssl.TrustManager[] trusts)
                                                 throws java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                                        java.security.KeyManagementException
        Creates an SSLContext. This is similar to Java-provided SSLContext.getInstance(), but serves as a utility method to consolidate such creations to ensure uniformity and easy adjustment of low-level SSL parameters to meet security goals. The returned SSLContext will already be initialized (init() already invoked).
        Parameters:
        trusts - array of TrustManagers to configure into the new context. Accepts and used as documented in SSLContext.init()
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException - if there is no underlying security provider registered with the JVM that can handle any of the TAK-preferred SSL protocols.
        java.security.KeyManagementException - if initialization of a new context fails
